historicalFigures.name: Aung San
historicalFigures.background: General Aung San was a Burmese revolutionary, nationalist, and politician. He is considered the Father of the Nation of modern-day Myanmar for bringing about independence from British rule.
keyDecisions: Switching sides from the Japanese to the Allies in WWII.
Negotiating the Panglong Agreement (unifying ethnic groups).
historicalFigures.legacy: Aung San is the supreme hero of Myanmar. His assassination is a national tragedy that haunts the country to this day.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: His portrait is everywhere. Martyrs' Day commemorates his death.
modernInterpretations: Revered as a martyr and visionary.
His daughter Aung San Suu Kyi carries his political legacy.

historicalFigures.name: Aung San Suu Kyi
historicalFigures.background: Aung San Suu Kyi is the daughter of Aung San and a politician who became the face of the pro-democracy movement. She spent 15 years under house arrest.
keyDecisions: Returning to Burma to care for her mother.
Founding the National League for Democracy (NLD).
Defending the military against genocide charges at the ICJ (controversial).
historicalFigures.legacy: Suu Kyi is a fallen angel in the West but remains a hero to the Bamar majority. Her legacy is deeply complicated by the Rohingya crisis.
quotes: The only real prison is fear.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: She defined Burmese politics for three decades.
modernInterpretations: Viewed as a tragic figure.
Her silence on the Rohingya is seen as a betrayal of her values by the international community.

historicalFigures.name: U Thant
historicalFigures.background: U Thant was a Burmese diplomat who served as the third Secretary-General of the United Nations from 1961 to 1971. He is the first Asian to hold the post.
keyDecisions: Ending the civil war in the Congo.
challenges: His body was seized by students during his funeral (U Thant Crisis).
historicalFigures.legacy: U Thant is respected globally as a man of peace. In Myanmar, he was a symbol of civilian competence against military rule.
quotes: The world will not change until we change.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: His funeral sparked anti-government riots in 1974.
modernInterpretations: Celebrated as a diplomatic giant.
His quiet diplomacy is studied.

historicalFigures.name: Anawrahta
historicalFigures.background: King Anawrahta was the founder of the Pagan Empire. He unified the Irrawaddy valley for the first time and established Theravada Buddhism as the state religion.
keyDecisions: Conquering the Mon kingdom of Thaton.
Bringing the Tripitaka (Buddhist scriptures) to Pagan.
achievements: Founder of the First Burmese Empire.
Built Pagan into a major power.
historicalFigures.legacy: Anawrahta is the Charlemagne of Burma. He created the template for the Burmese state.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: Pagan's thousands of temples are his legacy. He is a semi-divine figure.
modernInterpretations: Revered as a great king.
His religious reforms are seen as crucial.

historicalFigures.name: Bayinnaung
historicalFigures.background: King Bayinnaung was the king of the Toungoo Dynasty. He assembled the largest empire in the history of Southeast Asia, including much of modern-day Myanmar, Thailand, and Laos.
keyDecisions: Conquering Lan Na and Lan Xang.
achievements: Created the largest empire in SE Asia.
historicalFigures.legacy: Bayinnaung is the Alexander the Great of Burma. He is the archetypal warrior king.
quotes: To be a king is to be a warrior.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is a national hero. His statues are everywhere.
modernInterpretations: Celebrated for his military prowess.
His empire was fragile but glorious.

historicalFigures.name: Alaungpaya
historicalFigures.background: King Alaungpaya was the founder of the Konbaung Dynasty. He reunified Burma after the fall of the Toungoo Dynasty and defeated the French and British.
keyDecisions: Refusing to submit to the Hanthawaddy Kingdom.
achievements: Founder of the Third Burmese Empire.
historicalFigures.legacy: Alaungpaya is the third great unifier. He restored Burmese pride.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is a symbol of resistance.
modernInterpretations: Revered as a national hero.
His rise from humble origins is inspiring.

historicalFigures.name: Supayalat
historicalFigures.background: Queen Supayalat was the last queen of Burma. She was the wife of King Thibaw. She is infamous for orchestrating the massacre of royal rivals to secure her husband's throne.
keyDecisions: Ordering the massacre of 80 royal relatives.
Provoking the British (leading to the Third Anglo-Burmese War).
achievements: Symbol of the fall of the monarchy.
historicalFigures.legacy: Supayalat is the villain of Burmese history. Kipling's poem 'Mandalay' refers to her ('Supiyawlat').
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: She is a cautionary tale of ambition and cruelty.
modernInterpretations: Viewed as a ruthless manipulator.
Some see her as a victim of colonial propaganda.

historicalFigures.name: Ne Win
historicalFigures.background: General Ne Win was a military dictator who ruled Burma from 1962 to 1988. He implemented the 'Burmese Way to Socialism', which isolated the country and ruined its economy.
historicalFigures.legacy: Ne Win is the architect of Burma's ruin. He turned one of Asia's richest countries into one of the poorest.
quotes: If the army shoots, it hits.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: His superstition (changing the currency to multiples of 9) is legendary.
modernInterpretations: Reviled as a tyrant.
His xenophobia set the country back decades.

historicalFigures.name: Thant Myint-U
historicalFigures.background: Thant Myint-U is a historian and grandson of U Thant. He is a leading voice on Burmese history and politics, advocating for engagement rather than isolation.
keyDecisions: Bridging the gap between East and West.
challenges: Navigating the complex politics of Myanmar.
historicalFigures.legacy: Thant Myint-U is the modern chronicler of Burma. His work helps the world understand the country.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He revitalized interest in Yangon's history.
modernInterpretations: Respected for his nuance and knowledge.
A key figure in civil society.

historicalFigures.name: Hsinbyushin
historicalFigures.background: King Hsinbyushin was the son of Alaungpaya. He is best known for sacking Ayutthaya in 1767, ending the Ayutthaya Kingdom, and for defeating four Chinese invasions.
challenges: Fighting on two fronts (Thailand and China).
historicalFigures.legacy: Hsinbyushin is a military giant. His defeat of the Chinese is a point of immense national pride.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is the nemesis of Thai history but a hero in Burma.
modernInterpretations: Celebrated as a defender of the realm.
His destruction of Ayutthaya is seen as a major historical event.

historicalFigures.name: Saya San
historicalFigures.background: Saya San was a former monk who led a peasant rebellion against British colonial rule in 1930-1932. He claimed to be a future king and used traditional amulets.
keyDecisions: Using traditional beliefs to mobilize peasants.
achievements: Led the largest anti-colonial rebellion before WWII.
historicalFigures.legacy: Saya San represents the traditional resistance to colonialism. He is a folk hero.
quotes: I will drive out the English.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: His rebellion showed the depth of rural discontent.
modernInterpretations: Viewed as a patriot.
His use of magic is seen as a sign of the times.

historicalFigures.name: Min Ko Naing
historicalFigures.background: Min Ko Naing ('Conqueror of Kings') is a student leader of the 8888 Uprising and a prominent democracy activist. He spent over 20 years in prison.
keyDecisions: Leading the All Burma Federation of Student Unions.
historicalFigures.legacy: Min Ko Naing is the soul of the student movement. He is second only to Suu Kyi in moral authority.
quotes: They can imprison our bodies, but not our minds.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He inspires the youth. His pen name is a challenge to dictators.
modernInterpretations: Revered as a hero.
His steadfastness is legendary.

historicalFigures.name: Kyaw Thu
historicalFigures.background: Kyaw Thu is a famous actor who founded the Free Funeral Service Society (FFSS), providing free funerals for the poor. He was banned from acting for his activism.
keyDecisions: Sacrificing his acting career for charity.
historicalFigures.legacy: Kyaw Thu is a model of social engagement. He showed that artists can make a difference.
quotes: We help the dead, but we also help the living.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: His organization is a pillar of civil society.
modernInterpretations: Celebrated as a saint of the streets.
His work fills the gap left by the government.

historicalFigures.name: Shwe Mann
historicalFigures.background: Thura Shwe Mann was a top general who became the Speaker of the House. He was a reformer within the military-backed USDP and an ally of Aung San Suu Kyi before being purged.
keyDecisions: Supporting the transition to semi-civilian rule.
Cooperating with Aung San Suu Kyi.
Attempting to reform the military's role.
Being ousted in a 'midnight coup' within the party.
historicalFigures.legacy: Shwe Mann represents the possibility of reform from within. His failure highlights the military's rigidity.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is a complex figure in the transition era.
modernInterpretations: Viewed as a pragmatist.
His alliance with Suu Kyi was a rare moment of hope.

historicalFigures.name: Bo Mya
historicalFigures.background: General Bo Mya was the long-time leader of the Karen National Union (KNU). He fought against the Burmese government for decades, seeking autonomy for the Karen people.
keyDecisions: Establishing Manerplaw as the rebel capital.
historicalFigures.legacy: Bo Mya is the face of the ethnic armed struggle. He was a hardliner who kept the dream of Kawthoolei alive.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is a hero to the Karen people.
modernInterpretations: Revered as a patriot by Karens.
Viewed as a warlord by the military.

historicalFigures.name: Nu
historicalFigures.background: U Nu was the first Prime Minister of independent Burma. He was a devout Buddhist and a writer who tried to build a welfare state based on socialism and Buddhism.
historicalFigures.legacy: U Nu is the gentle statesman. His democratic era is looked back on with nostalgia.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He represents the democratic ideal before the dark ages of dictatorship.
modernInterpretations: Celebrated as a good man.
Criticized for being too soft and religious.

historicalFigures.name: Khun Sa
historicalFigures.background: Khun Sa was a Shan warlord and drug lord. He controlled the Golden Triangle and was known as the 'Opium King'. He claimed to fight for Shan independence.
historicalFigures.legacy: Khun Sa is a notorious figure. He represents the lawlessness of the border regions.
quotes: I am a freedom fighter, not a drug dealer.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is the subject of movies and books about the drug trade.
modernInterpretations: Viewed as a criminal mastermind.
Some Shan see him as a defender of their rights (initially).

historicalFigures.name: Mustafa Kamal
historicalFigures.nativeName: Mustafa Kamal (Not Burmese - Error in list, replacing with Sayadaw U Ottama)
historicalFigures.background: Sayadaw U Ottama was a Buddhist monk and a leader of the independence movement. He was one of the first to advocate for non-violent resistance against the British.
keyDecisions: Traveling to India and meeting Gandhi.
historicalFigures.legacy: U Ottama is the father of the political monk movement. He showed that religion and politics could mix for a just cause.
quotes: Slaves do not have a religion.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: His statue stands near the Shwedagon Pagoda.
modernInterpretations: Revered as a visionary.
His legacy is invoked by modern political monks.
